children.value: . It is most often used with
to expand grouped rows or on its own with nested
sets, but is not limited to these use-cases. It supports expanding rows both via internal table state and also via a hard-coded key on the raw row model.
The following options are supported via the main options object passed to
of expanded row IDs with boolean property values.
If a row's id is set to true in this object, that row will have an expanded state. For example, if
4th row in the original data array
would be expanded, since it would have that ID
to expand sub rows. For example, if
the 4th row would be expanded, along with the 6th subRow of the 4th row as well
This information is stored in state since the table is allowed to manipulate the filter through user interaction.
This string is used as the key to detect manual expanded state on any given row. For example, if a raw data row like
was detected, it would always be expanded, regardless of state.
, expanded rows are rendered along with normal rows.
, expanded rows will only be available through their parent row. This could be useful if you are implementing a custom expanded row view.
state will automatically reset if any of the following conditions are met:
For more information see the FAQ
"How do I stop my table state from automatically resetting when my data changes?"
The following properties are available on the table instance returned from
A function to toggle whether a row is expanded or not. The
boolean is optional, otherwise it will be a true toggle action
A function to toggle whether all of the rows in the table are expanded or not. The
boolean is optional, otherwise it will be a true toggle action
A prop getter function that returns all necessary props for an element to be clicked and toggle all of the rows expanded or not.

object returned by the table instance.
